etymology.interpretation: Originally a drawing of a hand axe: the long vertical suggests the handle and the hooked stroke the blade. Over time the form was regularized, and the word also came to denote the traditional weight unit ‘catty’.

examples.chinese: 我买了两斤苹果(我買了兩斤蘋果)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ mǎi le liǎng jīn píngguǒ.
examples.english: I bought two jin of apples.

examples.chinese: 这块肉一斤多一点(這塊肉一斤多一點)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè kuài ròu yì jīn duō yìdiǎn.
examples.english: This piece of meat is a bit over one jin.

examples.chinese: 这两支队伍水平半斤八两(這兩支隊伍水平半斤八兩)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè liǎng zhī duìwǔ shuǐpíng bàn jīn bā liǎng.
examples.english: These two teams are about the same level (six of one, half a dozen of the other).
